Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story: The line at the register snakes around the corner, and I can feel the tension in the air as customers clutch their last-minute holiday finds. As a cashier, I’m expected to keep my smile bright and my tone gentle, even as the woman in front of me raises her voice about a coupon that won’t scan. I nod, apologize, and try to soothe her, all while glancing at the clock. My shift as a volunteer at the community center starts in twenty minutes, and I remember the coordinator’s stern reminder: “Everyone must follow the new safety steps—no exceptions.” I promised I’d be there on time, ready to help, and to set an example by following every guideline. But here I am, stuck between the demands of my job and my commitment as a volunteer. My heart pounds as I try to balance the customer’s frustration with my own growing anxiety. I know I can’t let either side down, but the pressure of these conflicting expectations is almost too much to bear.
